journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Prediction of backside micromotion in total knee replacements by finite element simulation

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, Faculty of Engineering University of Manitoba, Canada
2Concordia Hip and Knee Institute, Concordia Joint Replacement Group, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Yunhua Luo, Department of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, Faculty of Engineering University of Manitoba, E2-327 Engineering Information and Technology Complex, Winnipeg, MB, R3T 2N2, Canada. Email: luoy@cc.umanitoba.ca

abstract.p: The micromotion at the interface between the polyethylene tibial insert and metal tibial tray, in modular total knee replacements, has been shown to contribute to wear particle-induced osteolysis and cause implant failure. Therefore, studying the design parameters that are involved in the backside wear process is an important task that may lead to improvement in new total knee replacements. In the present study, a finite element model was developed to predict the backside micromotion along the entire modular interface. Both the linear elastic constitutive model and non-linear J2-plasticity constitutive model were considered in the finite element model for polyethylene and were corroborated against published results obtained from displacement controlled knee simulator wear tests. The finite element simulation with the non-linear J2-plasticity constitutive model was able to more accurately predict backside micromotion, while the linear elastic constitutive model was not. The developed finite element model (including the non-linear J2-plasticity constitutive model) was then applied to assess the effects of the tibial tray locking mechanism design (dovetails versus full-peripheral design) and different levels of interference fit on insert micromotion. The developed finite element model, implementing the non-linear J2-plasticity constitutive model, was shown to successfully predict clinical amounts of backside micromotion and could be used for the design and development of total knee replacements for the reduction of backside micromotion and wear.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Wear-induced osteolysis, caused by the wear particles of ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene (PE) bearing components, is one of the factors that can limit the longevity of total knee replacements (TKRs).1 The backside surface has been identified as a significant source of wear particles possibly with an increased osteolytic potential.1–7 Backside wear has been shown to make a significant contribution to osteolysis,2–5 has been correlated with tibial osteolysis,4 and has been shown to account for up to 30% of total PE insert wear volume for some TKR designs.8 Therefore, there is great interest in reducing the micromotion and wear of the backside surface of PE inserts to improve the long term success of TKRs.

The loading and motion of the femoral component relative to the PE insert causes deformation of the insert and relative movement between the distal (backside) surface of the PE insert and the tibial tray of modular TKRs.1,3 The micromotion at the backside interface can generate PE wear particles that have been shown to be smaller in size than wear particles from the articulating surface.1,6,7 The smaller relative size of the PE particles may increase biological activity and osteolysis potential.9,10

The tibial tray surface finish and type of tibial tray locking mechanism design have been identified to affect backside wear.2–5,11–14 Grit-blasted surface finishes were shown to result in a greater amount of backside damage by the retrieval study of Brandt et al.13 The knee simulator wear experiments of McNulty and Swope15 demonstrated that a grit-blasted tibial tray surface increased PE wear by as much as 38% as a result of their higher tray surface roughness. Several retrieval studies11,12,16 have presented evidence that partial-peripheral locking mechanisms reduced backside damage over central locking mechanisms.

Knee simulator wear tests have been conducted to quantify the amount of micromotion and its effects on backside PE wear.15,17–19 However, the backside micromotion in such knee simulator wear tests can only be measured at specific locations around the peripheral surface of tibial inserts, while the micromotion of interest occurs across the entire backside surface. Thus, further knowledge on the magnitude of backside micromotion along the entire backside interface was deemed necessary to gain further insight in the aforementioned design parameters affecting backside wear and micromotion, which may lead to design improvements.

Finite element (FE) simulation could enable the assessment of backside micromotion along the entire backside interface, and is not associated with the limitations of high cost and time commitments of knee simulator wear testing, thus, making parametric analysis and iterative design optimization procedures more efficient.20 Nevertheless, the development of a FE model to predict backside micromotion was deemed to be a complex task as it requires the accurate assessment of the complex contact interactions and nonlinear material response to deformation. The reaction forces at the articular and backside surfaces of the PE insert depend upon a number of variables including the relative motion of each component in contact, the coefficient of friction, and the loading conditions of the contact interaction. The coefficient of friction between the components in contact may also depend upon the lubricant composition,21 thermal conditions,22 sliding velocity,23 and the contact pressure at the interface.24 The reaction forces result in the deformation of the PE insert and micromotion between the tibial tray and PE insert. Thus, the selected material model for PE could have a significant effect on the predicted micromotion, since the material’s mechanical properties determine the stress distribution and the deformation of the material. To date, FE modeling of PE has utilized various material models, including linear elasticity25–26 and non-linear models.27 Linear elastic models offer advantages such as simplicity and computational efficiency. Only Young’s modulus and Poisson’s ratio are required for a linear elastic model, however, a linear elastic model is not able to describe the characteristics of PE for medium-to-large strain values.28 A nonlinear material model such as the J2-plasticity model can better describe PE behavior. A J2-plasticity model is typically represented by a set of tabular stress–strain data obtained from experiments, which are used to construct piecewise linear interpolation functions between the data points. It has been demonstrated that a J2-plasticity model exhibits improved accuracy over the linear elastic model while still requiring a reasonable amount of computational time.27 The J2-placticity model, developed by Bergström et al.,27 predicted the mechanical behavior of PE with a coefficient of determination, a measure of how well the FE model predicted the outcome, of 0.877.27

In the present study, a FE model was developed with the goal of predicting the amount of backside micromotion at every location of the modular interface between the PE insert and the tibial tray, which cannot be measured during knee simulator wear testing alone. First, the FE model was developed to predict the micromotion at the backside surface of a TKR, and the model was corroborated by comparing the FE predicted micromotion with the measurements obtained from displacement controlled knee simulator experiments.15,17,29,30 Finally, the developed FE model was utilized to analyze the effects of different locking mechanism types, as well as different levels of interference fit on backside micromotion.

sec.title: Development and corroboration of FE model
sec.p: The Anatomic Modular Knee (AMK®, DePuy Orthopedics Inc., Warsaw, IN), a modular fixed bearing TKR, was selected for studying backside micromotion. The AMK® was selected because it was previously estimated to hold a large percentage of the TKR market,31 and it was considered possible that dovetail-type locking mechanisms, such as that of the AMK®, might permit a greater amount of backside micromotion to occur, therefore, resulting in an increased risk of wear particle-induced osteolysis.11,12,16 The AMK® was available with either a grit-blasted Ti–6Al–4V (Ti)-alloy tibial tray or with a polished cobalt-chromium (CoCr)-alloy (ASTM-F75) tibial tray. Both trays were of the same geometry, but include different substrate materials and surface finishes. The arithmetic average roughness coefficients of Ra = 1.05 ± 0.06 μm and Ra = 0.02 ± 0.01 μm were reported for the grit-blasted Ti-alloy tibial tray and the polished CoCr-alloy tibial tray respectively.30

Published knee simulator experiments implementing the AMK® are also available for the purpose of corroboration. DiSilvestro et al.17 and McNulty et al.15,29,30 investigated the effects of surface finish and PE locking mechanism on the AMK®. The experiments of DiSilvestro et al.17 and McNulty et al.15,29,30 shared the same experimental set-up for the measurement of micromotion during knee simulator tests. Miniature differential variable reluctance transducers (DVRTs) were utilized for the measurement of micromotion, with a resolution of 200 nm and a maximum displacement of 750 µm.15,17,29,30 The DVRTs were placed at the lateral edge of the insert, as well as at the most posterior point of the medial and lateral condyles. The bracket that the DVRTs were attached to was directly fixed to the tibial tray so that micromotion is measured as PE insert movement relative to the tibial tray.15,17,29,30 The experiments of DiSilvestro et al.17 and McNulty et al.15,29,30 incorporated the loading conditions of ISO 14243-3:2009, loading and displacement parameters for wear-testing machines with displacement control and corresponding environmental conditions for test.32 The ISO standard specifies the flexion–extension profile, dynamic loading, anterior–posterior (AP) displacements, and internal–external rotation to simulate a level walking gait cycle at 1 Hz (Figure 1).

caption.p: ISO 14243-3 gait cycle (a) flexion–extension angle; (b) axial loading; (c) anterior–posterior displacement; (d) internal–external rotation.

sec.p: DiSilvestro et al.17 presented the typical average AP micromotion, during knee simulator testing, plotted over a single ISO gait cycle for the AMK® with a grit-blasted Ti-alloy tibial tray, ranging approximately 0–70 µm. McNulty et al.29,30 reported the maximum AP micromotion of each condyle during the ISO gait cycle for the AMK® with a polished CoCr tray. The results were obtained over two million cycles (Mc) for three TKRs. The resulting maximum AP micromotion with the polished CoCr-alloy tibial tray was 510 ± 275 µm and 345 ± 190 µm (magnitude ± variance) for the medial and lateral sides respectively.29–30

Solid models of a Size 3 femoral component, and a Size 3 tibial tray were constructed based on manufacturing drawings (DePuy Orthopedics Inc., Warsaw, IN). A solid model of a Size 3–4, 10 mm nominal thickness, cruciate retaining PE insert was also provided by DePuy (Figure 2).

caption.p: Model of the AMK® with loading and displacement (‘+’ indicates positive direction).

sec.p: A FE model was developed using Abaqus/Explicit (Abaqus 6.101, Simulia, Providence, RI). A realistic constitutive model for the PE insert was vital to the success of the model for the prediction of backside micromotion. Two different constitutive models were implemented, the linear elastic model and a nonlinear model based on the true stress–strain behavior of PE. The linear elastic model was considered for its simplicity, computational efficiency, and owing to its popular application for the modeling of PE in the literature.25–26 The linear elastic constitutive model has a modulus of elasticity of 680 MPa and a Poisson’s ratio of 0.46.28 The nonlinear model was implemented by means of the J2-plasticity theory. The J2-plasticity material parameters utilized by Bergström et al.,27 for the simulation of PE under cyclic loading as well as small, intermediate, and large monotonic deformations, were adopted. The J2-plasticity model included a modulus of elasticity of 1051 MPa, a Poisson’s ratio of 0.46, and the nonlinear tabular stress–strain values listed in Table 1. The model includes an elastic component defined by the modulus of elasticity and Poisson’s ratio, as well as a plastic component defined by the linear interpolation functions of the tabular stress–strain values. The model was preconditioned to ensure that the plastic response of the PE insert had stabilized by repeating the step that recreated the conditions of the stated ISO standard until the peak cumulative micromotion converged to within 5% of the previous step’s values without any oscillation between results.

caption.p: Nonlinear stress (σy)–stain (ϵp ) values adopted for the J2-plasticity model.27

sec.p: The PE insert was modeled as a deformable body with a density of 0.936 g/cm3.28 Both the femoral component and tibial tray were modeled as rigid bodies to reduce computational time, since both the CoCr alloy and the Ti alloy have moduli of elasticity far greater than that of the PE insert.28 The contact interaction between the components was modeled as penalty contact. The femoral–PE interface included a coefficient of friction of 0.04, a value in agreement with experimental tests.26,33,34

Mixed hexahedron–tetrahedron meshes dominated by hexahedrons were adopted in the FE model. The hexahedral elements were used for their relatively higher convergence rate and the tetrahedral elements for their flexibility in dealing with complex geometry. Mesh densities were determined by a mesh sensitivity study based on a prescribed accuracy requirement of less than 5% variance in peak sliding distance without oscillation between meshes as the mesh density was increased (Table 2).

caption.p: Mesh sensitivity analysis parameters for the FE model of the AMK®.

tr.th: Number of elements used for components (×104)

sec.p: The loading and boundary conditions were applied according to the ISO-stated loading conditions. The internal-external (IE) rotation and AP displacement were implemented as boundary conditions on the tibial tray (Figure 2). These boundary conditions were specified using the reference point placed at the intersection of the axis of the tibial tray stem and the tray–insert interface. The axial load was applied to the tibial tray, offset in the medial direction from the tibial tray’s reference point by 7% of the trays width, as per the stated ISO standard. The flexion of the knee was recreated by the rotation of the femoral component, by means of a boundary condition, about a reference axis placed at the ISO specified flexion–extension axis location.

The AP micromotion was calculated by comparing the most posterior node of each condyle on the peripheral–distal edge of the insert to the tibial tray node directly below it. This method of calculating AP micromotion was consistent with the measurement system of the in vitro knee simulator experiments.17,29,30 Similarly the medial–lateral (ML) micromotion was calculated at the insert node of the most lateral point, compared to the node of the tibial tray directly below it, also in agreement with the method of the in vitro knee simulator experiments.17,29,30 The average AP micromotion was determined by averaging the AP values from each condyle. Since backside wear is proportional to the cumulative relative sliding distances, not the maximum displacement from the initial state, cumulative micromotion was calculated for each node of the backside surface. Two trays having different surface roughness’s, a blasted Ti-alloy tray, and a polished CoCr-alloy tray, were studied by FE simulations and compared to the corresponding knee simulator results for each type of tibial tray.

Ti-alloy tray experiment. The micromotion of the AMK® with a blasted Ti-alloy tibial tray over the ISO gait cycle was simulated and compared to the knee simulator results. The PE–Ti interface was modeled with a coefficient of friction of 0.5, based on experimental results.35 The objective of the simulation with the Ti-alloy tibial tray was to compare the FE simulation trend of the average AP micromotion over the ISO gait cycle for each constitutive model with that of the knee simulator results.

CoCr alloy tray experiment. The micromotion was also simulated for the AMK® with a polished CoCr-alloy tray. The CoCr-on-PE contact interaction included a coefficient of friction of 0.04, a value in agreement with experimental tests.26,33,34 The objective of the CoCr-alloy tray simulation was to evaluate the ability of the model to predict the proper maximum micromotion magnitude of each condyle.

sec.title: Cumulative micromotion of backside surface
sec.p: A compression test was conducted to analyze the significance of obtaining micromotion predictions for the entire backside PE surface, compared with relying on the peripheral measurements a knee simulator test would provide. The compression test was conducted by incrementally adding and removing a load of 2600 N, using tabular equally spaced intervals, to the femoral component while the tibial tray remained fixed. The compression of the femoral component against the PE insert was the only relative motion applied during the simulation. The cumulative micromotion of the backside surface during the stated ISO simulated gait cycle was also analyzed to consider the increased amount of backside micromotion information obtained by the FE simulation over knee simulator experimentation alone.

sec.title: Analysis of tibial locking mechanism design
sec.p: Two different locking mechanisms were analyzed to assess the influence of the locking mechanism design on backside micromotion. A comparison was conducted between the AMK® with a dovetail and pin locking mechanism and the AMK® with a modified peripheral locking mechanism. The peripheral locking mechanism was similar to that of the Press-Fit Condylar knee system (PFC®, DePuy Orthopedics Inc., Warsaw, IN). The PFC®-type locking mechanism was applied to the AMK® insert in order to enable a direct comparison of the locking mechanism performance without altering the reaction forces of the topside surface. A laser scanner (Ai600 ShapeGrabber, Ottawa, Ontario) was used to generate solid models of the PFC® PE insert and tibial tray. The solid models of the AMK® insert and the tibial tray were modified to include the PFC®-type full peripheral locking mechanism and remove the original dovetail and pin locking mechanism (Figure 3). The tibial tray surfaces of the two designs were modeled with a polished CoCr alloy surface.

caption.p: Tibial tray comparison: (a) typical AMK® tray with a dovetail locking mechanism; (b) modified AMK® tray with a PFC® type full peripheral locking mechanism; both trays exhibit a polished CoCr alloy bearing surface.

sec.p: The influence of interference fit on backside micromotion was also analyzed. Interference fit (press fit), refers to the amount of geometrical overlap (interference) between two components. Once the two components are pressed together, the PE deforms (resulting in strain) to fit the geometry of the tray and results in pressure between the two components. The measure of interference fit of the AMK® with the PFC®-type locking mechanism was varied from size-on-size to 0.254 mm. The femoral component and tibial tray were, once again, modeled as rigid bodies for computational efficiency. The PE insert was modeled with the nonlinear J2-plasticity model of Bergström et al.27 Penalty contact was defined between all contacting components and the CoCr-on-PE contact interaction included a coefficient of friction of 0.04.26,33,34 Loading and boundary conditions were once again applied according to the stated ISO standard. The mesh densities of the PFC®-type design were determined by a mesh sensitivity analysis (Table 3).

caption.p: Mesh sensitivity analysis parameters for the FE model of the modified AMK®, including a PFC® type peripheral locking mechanism.

tr.th: Number of elements used for components (×104)

sec.title: Development and corroboration of the FE model
sec.p: Convergence tests were performed to analyze mesh sensitivity and the stabilization of the materials plasticity (Figures 4 and 5). The mesh sensitivity analysis revealed an element edge size control of 0.889 mm to be sufficient for the prediction of backside micromotion. The materials plasticity stabilization analysis showed the difference from the second cycle to subsequent cycles to be less than 0.5%. Therefore, one preconditioning cycle was implemented and the second cycle was utilized for the analysis of backside micromotion.

caption.p: Mesh sensitivity analysis using maximum cumulative sliding distance (µm) over repeated cycles for typical AMK® tray with a dovetail locking mechanism modified AMK® tray with a PFC® type full peripheral locking mechanism.

Plasticity stabilization using maximum cumulative sliding distance (µm) over repeated cycles for typical AMK® tray with a dovetail locking mechanism modified AMK® tray with a PFC® type full peripheral locking mechanism.

sec.p: Ti-alloy tray results. The average AP micromotion of the knee simulator results17 and the predicted amount of micromotion using the linear elastic model and the J2-plasticity model for the AMK® with a blasted Ti-alloy tray are shown in Figure 6. As can be seen from the results, the linear elastic model does not predict the trend as successfully as the J2-plasticity model. The J2-plasticity model predicted similar micromotion to the knee simulator results during the majority of the ISO gait cycle, but under predicts the micromotion during the swing phase (from approximately 60–95% of the gait cycle). However, the FE results are within reasonable proximity to the knee simulator results for this deviation to be explained by the experimental variation of knee simulator results.

caption.p: Average micromotion in the AP direction during one gait cycle following ISO 14243-3 for the AMK® with a grit blasted Ti-Alloy tray.

sec.p: CoCr-alloy tray results. The maximum micromotion at each point of interest on the peripheral surface of the insert was determined for the AMK® with a CoCr-alloy tray. The FE simulation results obtained with both the linear elastic and the J2-plasticity model are listed in Table 4, along with the magnitude and variance from the knee simulator results. The maximum AP micromotion of the medial and lateral condyles of both the linear elastic model and the J2-plasticity model fell within the variation of the knee simulator results. However, the linear elastic model and the J2-plasticity model predicted significantly different results for the ML micromotion and internal–external rotation for the CoCr-alloy tray.

caption.p: Backside micromotion results for the AMK® with a polished CoCr tray.

sec.p: The maximum AP micromotion of each condyle for the AMK® with a polished CoCr tray is shown in Figure 7. The knee simulator results show a greater amount of micromotion on the medial condyle, as a result of the load being offset towards the medial side as specified by the stated ISO standard. The linear elastic model failed to replicate this medial–lateral difference and predicted only a small difference between the two condyles (32 µm). Conversely, the J2-plasticity model predicted a larger difference between the medial and lateral sides (159 µm), accurately replicating the behavior seen from the knee simulator experiments.

caption.p: Maximum micromotion in the AP direction during one gait cycle of ISO 14243-3 for the AMK® with a polished CoCr alloy tray (error bars indicate 95% confidence interval).

sec.p: The AP micromotion of each condyle over the ISO gait cycle for the AMK® with a CoCr-alloy tray is shown in Figure 8. The difference in phase between the two condyles is evident, resulting in the overall internal–external rotation of the PE insert relative to the tibial tray. This rotation is likely responsible for the stippling marks that have been observed for the AMK® on components retrieved from patients.15,36

caption.p: J2-Plasticity model predicted micromotion of the medial and lateral condyles in the AP direction during one gait cycle following ISO 14243-3 for the AMK® with a polished CoCr-alloy tray.

sec.title: Cumulative micromotion of backside surface
sec.p: FE simulation was utilized to evaluate the cumulative micromotion of the backside surface under a compression load. While knee simulator tests would only be able to provide measurements of the micromotion around the periphery of the insert, FE simulation results are capable of predicting backside micromotion across the entire backside surface (Figure 9). The use of the FE simulation also enabled the quantification of the relative sliding distances at each location on the backside surface during the stated ISO gait cycle (Figure 10).

caption.p: J2-plasticity model predicted cumulative micromotion for the AMK® tibial insert backside surface, with a polished CoCr-alloy tray, during compressive loading only.
J2-plasticity model predicted cumulative micromotion for the AMK® tibial insert backside surface, with a polished CoCr-alloy tray, during one gait cycle following ISO 14243-3.

sec.title: Analysis of tibial locking mechanism design
sec.p: Convergence analyses were conducted for the PFC®-type design. The mesh sensitivity analysis revealed an element edge size control of 1.016 mm to be sufficient for the prediction of backside (Figure 4). The plasticity stabilization analysis revealed once again that only one preconditioning cycle was necessary and the data from the second cycle was used for the analysis (Figure 5).

The dovetail type locking mechanism of the AMK® was compared with the peripheral type locking mechanism adapted from the PFC®. The PFC®-type design resulted in greatly decreased micromotion over the locking mechanism design of the AMK® (Figures 10 and 11). The majority of micromotion for both designs occurred beneath the medial condyle and around the locking mechanism interface resulting from the deformation of the PE under loading.

The method’s ability to efficiently analyze various designs was further demonstrated by analyzing the effect of interference fit between the PE insert and the tibial tray for the AMK® with the PFC®-type locking mechanism (Figures 11 and 12). The analysis revealed that increasing the interference fit from size-on-size to 0.254 mm interference reduced cumulative backside micromotion by 9.88%. The location of maximum backside micromotion for the PFC®-type design occurred on the medial side of the implant along the PE-tray locking mechanism interface (Figure 13).

caption.p: J2-plasticity model predicted cumulative micromotion for the modified AMK® tibial insert backside surface including a PFC® type peripheral locking mechanism of 0.254 mm interference fit, with a polished CoCr-alloy tray, during one gait cycle following ISO 14243-3.

J2-plasticity model predicted cumulative micromotion for the modified AMK® tibial insert backside surface including a PFC® type peripheral locking mechanism of size-on-size interference fit, with a polished CoCr-alloy tray, during one gait cycle following ISO 14243-3.

J2-plasticity model predicted cumulative micromotion for the modified AMK® tibial insert backside interface including a PFC® type peripheral locking mechanism of 0.254 mm interference fit, with a polished CoCr-alloy tray, during one gait cycle following ISO 14243-3: (a) view from the medial side showing the location of maximum micromotion; (b) sectioned view from the articular surfacetowards the distal surface.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: To the authors’ knowledge, this study presents the first FE model that permits the researcher and implant designer to predict the amount of backside micromotion of the modular TKR. The J2-plasticity model behaved much more accurately, in comparison to the knee simulator results, than the linear elastic model. The linear elastic model was proven to be an oversimplification of the material, and has previously been shown to exhibit accurate material response only for small strain values.28 The second material model implemented the true stress–strain behavior of PE by means of the J2-plasticity theory. Although the J2-plasticity model does have several disadvantages compared to more advanced material models, the J2-plasticity model has an excellent balance of computational efficiency and accuracy.27 Some of the shortcomings of the J2-plasticity model include predicted piecewise linear behavior owing to the linear interpolation between the points of the tabular stress–strain values. The J2-plasticity model does not account for strain-rate dependant behavior. The model also predicts linear unloading behavior rather than the nonlinear behavior of PE.27 However, the model has been shown to perform well in comparison with physical material testing (r2 = 0.877),27 and more accurately predicted the AP micromotion magnitude and trend over the ISO gait cycle.

FE simulation with the proposed model is capable of predicting the micromotion in all regions of the backside surface, whereas only peripheral points can be monitored during in vitro knee simulator testing. Peripheral measurements are insensitive to the majority of micromotion that occurs on the backside surface and, therefore, provide a poor measure of implant performance with respect to backside micromotion (Figure 9).

During the ISO gait cycle the greatest amounts of micromotion were identified to occur in the region below the femoral condyles and near the interface of the locking mechanism (Figures 10 and 11). The evaluation of relative sliding vectors at each location provides micromotion information that is not obtainable through the use of in vitro knee simulators, yet could be used to improve the designs of locking mechanisms.

The peripheral locking mechanism design resulted in greatly decreased cumulative micromotion values over the dovetail locking mechanism of the AMK® (Figures 10 and 11). The results of the FE simulation are in agreement with the retrieval study results11,12,16 that have indicated that peripheral type locking mechanisms reduce backside damage compared with central locking mechanisms.

The analysis of locking mechanism interference fit revealed that increasing the amount of interference fit results in increased initial stresses in the PE, providing increased stiffness and, therefore, decreased relative movement in response to loading (Figures 11 and 13). Furthermore, increased interference fit would be beneficial to the design to avoid introducing laxity between the components as a result of creep and other forms of PE damage over time.

The FE model predicted micromotion results have to be compared with clinical results as part of the development process. Unfortunately, there is limited information available regarding the quantification of in vivo micromotion. Therefore, the results of the present study were compared with clinical results of a different implant design in order to serve as an indication of approximate micromotion magnitude that the TKR may experience in vivo. Tibial trays fixed to the bone by screws include a recess for the screw heads. The plastic flow properties of PE may result in protrusions into the screw hole recesses on the backside surface of PE tibial inserts.37 The AP micromotion results in the formation of oblong screw hole protrusions, rather than round protrusions, corresponding to the PE tibial insert motion relative to the screw hole recesses.4,37,38 These screw hole protrusions have been shown to be as much as 600 µm out of round, indicating 600 µm of maximum displacement.4 These clinical results are of similar magnitude to the FE model predicted micromotion results for TKRs with a polished CoCr-alloy tray (Figures 7, 8, 10–13), indicating that the FE predicted micromotion is within the range of reported clinical micromotion magnitude.

The FE simulation results corroborated well with the available knee simulator results, although further testing to investigate the effects of different test conditions and different implant designs on the model’s accuracy could be conducted. For the evaluation of backside micromotion it is recommended that the FE simulation be performed in combination with knee simulator testing. In such cases, the micromotion of peripheral points from the knee simulator results could be used to evaluate the models accuracy under the given conditions, while the FE simulation could provide the micromotion results for the entire backside surface.

The scope of the current work was limited to the prediction of micromotion, not PE wear. However, a computational wear model could be applied to the results to predict the backside wear. Furthermore, the predicted micromotion results are only accurate for the initial stages of the implants life, as the PE material around the locking mechanisms is subject to wear, creep, and deformation, which may result in increased laxity over time. Therefore, for the simulation of micromotion throughout the lifecycle of the implant, the micromotion model must be combined with a wear and damage model that regularly updates the implant geometry to account for the PE damage over time. It is recommended that the FE micromotion simulation procedure be implemented in combination with knee simulator experimentation for the evaluation of backside micromotion, and the design of new tibial tray locking mechanisms.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A FE simulation method was developed for the prediction of backside micromotion. Two different constitutive models were implemented, a simple linear elastic model, and a nonlinear J2-plasticity model. The predicted micromotion of the J2-plasticity model corroborated well with knee simulator results and provided improved accuracy over the linear elastic model. The model was utilized to analyze two different locking mechanism designs and two levels of interference fit. The peripheral locking mechanism of a PFC®-type design was demonstrated to result in decreased micromotion in comparison to the dovetail design of the AMK®. As well, increased interference fit was demonstrated to reduce backside micromotion. Both trends are in agreement with the results of knee simulator wear tests and clinical results. The FE simulation featured improved time and cost efficiency over in vitro knee simulators and provided complementary information, therefore, it is recommended that both simulations be conducted in combination, for the analysis of backside micromotion and backside wear. The method is promising as a supplemental procedure to improve TKR designs for the reduction of backside micromotion and wear.

ack.p: The authors would like to thank DePuy for providing the manufacturing drawings of the AMK® femoral and tibial tray components, as well as the computer-aided design model of the AMK® tibial insert.

fn.p: Sean O’Brien received Scholarships from the Mathematics of Information Technology and Complex Systems (MITACS), Matrix Biomedical Inc. and the Musculoskeletal Innovation Product Development Centre.
The authors declare that there is no conflict of interest.
